docs.title: CORE — Community Obsidian Resource Exchange
docs.text:
CORE is an open, community-driven knowledge base for computer science, software engineering, cybersecurity, cloud, and AI.

The project is designed to take learners from beginner → advanced through structured notes, hands-on labs, and concise cheatsheets — all built openly by the community.

docs.title: 🧠 Notes
docs.text: Organized by skill level and domain: - Beginner → fundamentals and mental models - Intermediate → practical systems and workflows - Advanced → specialization and deep dives

docs.title: 🧪 Labs
docs.text: Hands-on exercises designed to reinforce concepts through practice.

docs.title: 📄 Cheatsheets
docs.text: Quick-reference material for commands, syntax, and workflows.

docs.title: Who This Is For
docs.text:
• Self-taught learners
  • Students and career switchers
  • Working professionals refreshing fundamentals
  • Contributors who want to teach at scale

docs.title: How to Contribute
docs.text: If you want to help build CORE: - Read CONTRIBUTING.md - Use the templates in /templates - Start with a beginner note or lab

docs.title: Status
docs.text:
🚧 CORE is actively under construction. Structure is stable; content is growing.

Start with Beginner → Computer Science → What is a Computer?

docs.title: CORE — Community Obsidian Resource Exchange
docs.text:
An open, community-driven vault of notes for computer science, coding, and cybersecurity.

🌱 Our goal: Create the world’s most comprehensive open learning resource, making it easy for beginners to start and grow all the way to advanced topics like red teaming, cloud security, and AI.

docs.title: 🚀 Mission
docs.text:
• Make knowledge open, structured, and easy to explore.
  • Help beginners and experts alike learn, teach, and contribute.
  • Keep resources free and community-owned.

docs.title: CORE Roadmap
docs.text: CORE is built in public and evolves in stages.

docs.title: Phase 1 — Foundations (current)
docs.text:
• Stable taxonomy
  • Beginner core notes
  • MkDocs site online

docs.title: Phase 2 — Expansion
docs.text:
• Intermediate systems content
  • Hands-on labs
  • Contributor onboarding

docs.title: Phase 3 — Depth
docs.text:
• Advanced security, cloud, and AI
  • Community curation
  • Quality scoring and reviews

docs.title: Library
docs.text:
The reference layer of CORE: definitions, curated resources, tools, patterns, checklists, and playbooks.

Use this when you need: - a definition (glossary) - a reference (commands, protocols, APIs) - a workflow (checklists/playbooks) - a curated path (reading lists)

docs.title: AI
docs.text: Advanced AI topics with practical engineering and security awareness.

docs.title: Focus
docs.text:
• Training vs inference basics
  • Evaluation and failure modes
  • Prompt injection / data leakage concerns

docs.title: Cloud Security
docs.text: Securing identity, networks, data, and workloads in cloud environments.

docs.title: Focus
docs.text:
• IAM design and least privilege
  • Network exposure + segmentation
  • Secrets and key management
  • Misconfiguration patterns

docs.title: Malware
docs.text: High-level malware understanding for defensive awareness.

docs.title: Focus
docs.text:
• Execution flow and persistence concepts
  • Safe analysis setup (lab discipline)
  • Detection and IOCs

docs.title: Red Teaming
docs.text: Adversary simulation to improve defense.

docs.title: Focus
docs.text:
• Recon and initial access concepts
  • Post-exploitation fundamentals
  • Reporting and remediation mindset
  • Ethics and safety boundaries

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: A computer is a machine that takes input, processes it according to instructions, stores data, and produces output. Most computers share the same fundamental architecture: computation (CPU), memory (RAM), storage (SSD/HDD), and input/output devices. Understanding these components helps you reason about performance, debugging, and how software interacts with hardware.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: • None

docs.title: Input → Process → Output
docs.text:
• Input: data enters the system (keyboard, mouse, files, network)
  • Process: instructions execute on the CPU
  • Output: results leave the system (screen, files, network)

docs.title: CPU (Central Processing Unit)
docs.text:
• Executes instructions
  • Performance depends on cores, clock speed, cache, and workload type

docs.title: Memory (RAM)
docs.text:
• Fast, temporary storage
  • Cleared when power is lost
  • Insufficient RAM leads to swapping and slowdowns

docs.title: Storage (SSD/HDD)
docs.text:
• Persistent data storage
  • SSDs are faster than HDDs for most workloads

docs.title: Input/Output (I/O)
docs.text:
• Communication paths between components
  • Disk, network, USB, display all count as I/O

docs.title: Commands / Code
docs.text:
Check system information on Linux:

```bash uname -a lscpu free -h lsblk

docs.title: Git Fundamentals
docs.text: Git is the standard tool for tracking changes and collaborating.

docs.title: You’ll learn
docs.text:
• Commits, branches, merges
  • Pull requests and reviews
  • Undoing mistakes safely
  • Clean history practices

docs.title: Linux Fundamentals
docs.text: This section introduces Linux as a daily environment for development, cloud, and security work.

docs.title: You’ll learn
docs.text:
• Shell navigation and core commands
  • Filesystem layout and permissions
  • Processes, services, and logs
  • Installing and updating software

docs.title: Networking Fundamentals
docs.text: Networking is how computers communicate—locally and over the internet.

docs.title: You’ll learn
docs.text:
• IP, DNS, ports, and protocols
  • TCP vs UDP mental model
  • Basic troubleshooting tools (ping, curl, traceroute)
  • Why this matters for web, cloud, and security

docs.title: Cloud
docs.text: Cloud is rented infrastructure + managed services.

docs.title: You’ll learn
docs.text:
• Compute, storage, networking primitives
  • IAM basics (identity/permissions)
  • Containers and deployment patterns
  • Observability basics

docs.title: Databases
docs.text: Storing, modeling, and querying data reliably.

docs.title: You’ll learn
docs.text:
• Relational vs non-relational concepts
  • SQL basics and indexing intuition
  • Transactions and consistency
  • Practical modeling patterns

docs.title: Security
docs.text: Defensive fundamentals and secure workflows.

docs.title: You’ll learn
docs.text:
• Threat modeling basics
  • Authentication vs authorization
  • Dependency hygiene
  • Logging and incident fundamentals

docs.title: Web Systems
docs.text: How browsers, servers, and APIs work together.

docs.title: You’ll learn
docs.text:
• HTTP/HTTPS, headers, cookies
  • Sessions and authentication basics
  • API fundamentals (REST concepts)
  • Where common security issues show up
